newsitem.title: UK: Greenpeace British oil case to resume in September.
newsitem.headline: Greenpeace British oil case to resume in September.

text.p: Greenpeace accused the British government and leading oil firms in London's High Court on Thursday of plundering the environment with oil exploration of the north Atlantic.
After hearing Greenpeace's initial application, the judge said he would hold a two-day hearing in September where evidence would be heard supporting and opposing the group's objections.
This hearing could lead to the environmental group being given leave to apply for a full judicial review of government licensing policy.

"This is a case of considerable importance, high sensitivity and national interest for all parties concerned. This is a matter of some urgency," Judge Martin Tucker was quoted as saying by Greenpeace.
Greenpeace contends the British government acted unlawfully in issuing licences for oil exploration while failing to consider their responsibilities under international environmental directives.

"This fight is over an ocean wilderness that is home to whales, dolphins and world heritage site for birds as well as a deep water coral," Lord Melchett, executive director of the environmental pressure group, said in a statement. "We also oppose further oil exploitation on the grounds that fossil fuels are damaging the climate," he said.
Greenpeace said its case was opposed by 22 oil firms.
It wants the court to suspend exploration licences granted to oil companies in the government's latest offshore licensing round.

Greenpeace believes the government has failed to apply the European Habitats Directive when it awarded permits in the 17th offshore licensing around the Rockall Trough west of the Hebrides and north of the Shetland Islands.
Last month, Greenpeace activists sailed inflatable boats close to a Texaco oil exploration vessel in the north Atlantic in an attempt to stop seismic testing.
Activists occupied the London office of U.S. oil company Conoco, another company awarded an Atlantic exploration licence.
Greenpeace campaigners also seized the tiny, barren Atlantic island of Rockall and, rejecting British claims, proclaimed a new state of Waveland.
